title: Rooted to Rise
teaser: When your roots go deep enough, rising becomes natural
theme: How rooted rest produces lasting strength, purpose, and fruitful influence in your circles

emphasis: mount up with wings like eagles
modules.hebrewOriginal: וְקוֹיֵ יְהוָה יַחֲלִיפוּ כֹחַ יַעֲלוּ אֵבֶר כַּנְּשָׁרִים יָרוּצוּ וְלֹא יִיגָעוּ יֵלְכוּ וְלֹא יִיעָפוּ
modules.passage: But they who wait for the Lord shall renew their strength; they shall mount up with wings like eagles; they shall run and not be weary; they shall walk and not faint.

modules.meaning: to wait, to hope, to look eagerly for
modules.rootMeaning: Qavah literally means to bind together, like twisting strands into a rope. Waiting on God is not passive idling. It is the active binding of your hope to His promise. The person who waits on God is not doing nothing. They are weaving their trust into something unbreakable.
modules.usageNote: The renewal Isaiah describes uses the Hebrew yachalifu, which means to exchange or replace. Those who wait on God do not simply get more energy. They receive an entirely different kind of strength, one exchanged for their exhaustion. You trade your weakness for God's power.

wordByWord.meaning: and those who wait for, who hope in

relatedWords.reference: Tiqvah (hope) shares the same root as qavah. In Hebrew, hope and waiting are the same word. Biblical hope is not wishful thinking but active, bound-together waiting.

modules.body:
Isaiah 40 was written to exiles. The people of Judah had been torn from their land, their temple destroyed, their identity shattered. Into that devastation, Isaiah delivered one of Scripture's most soaring promises: those who wait on the Lord will exchange their exhaustion for His strength.

The sequence Isaiah describes is unexpected. You would expect it to build from walking to running to flying. Instead, it moves in reverse: mount up with wings, then run, then walk. The order reveals something about the nature of faith-based endurance. The dramatic moments of soaring are real, but the hardest test is the daily walk, the ordinary faithfulness that persists when the adrenaline fades.

Isaiah's promise is not that you will never grow tired. It is that the tiredness will not end you. Those who bind their hope to God receive a different fuel source. They walk and do not faint. Not because they are stronger, but because they are connected to an inexhaustible supply.
modules.keyInsight: Isaiah's sequence moves from flying to running to walking. The greatest test of faith is not the dramatic soaring but the daily walk that continues when no one is watching.

modules.heading: The Reverse Sequence of Strength

modules.body:
Chad Reynolds's company OCEAN continues to support tech entrepreneurs who lead with faith, values, and balance. What started as a personal rescue from burnout became a sustained ministry to others facing the same pressure. Chad now mentors emerging leaders, not with a formula for success, but with a testimony of what happens when you let God redirect your ambition.

The resolution of Chad's story is not a dramatic climax. It is an ongoing walk. Daily choices to prioritize presence over performance. Weekly rhythms that honor rest. Consistent mentoring conversations where he tells younger founders: the burnout you are racing toward is not the end of the road. It is an invitation to let God rebuild the road.

The fruit of Chad's rooted life is not just personal peace. It is influence. The people around him, the startups he supports, the leaders he mentors, all benefit from a man who stopped running long enough to grow roots.
modules.connectionToTheme: Chad's story resolves not in a single dramatic moment but in sustained, daily faithfulness. His rooted presence has become a source of life for others, illustrating Isaiah's promise that waiting on God produces strength that endures.

modules.heading: The Ongoing Walk

modules.body:
Paul told the Galatians, 'Let us not grow weary of doing good, for in due season we will reap, if we do not give up' (Galatians 6:9). The Greek for 'grow weary' is enkakomen, meaning to lose heart, to become faint-spirited. Paul does not promise instant results. He promises harvest in due season, but only for those who persist.

Jesus grounded this further in the vine metaphor: 'I am the vine; you are the branches. Whoever abides in me and I in him, he it is that bears much fruit, for apart from me you can do nothing' (John 15:5). The word 'abide' (meno) means to remain, to stay, to dwell. Fruitfulness is not the result of effort. It is the result of staying connected.

This is the theological foundation for everything this week has been about. Stillness, purpose, patience under pressure, grace under accusation, and now sustained faithfulness: all of it flows from abiding. The branch does not strain to produce fruit. It remains attached to the vine.
modules.historicalContext: Isaiah 40 marks the beginning of what scholars call 'Second Isaiah' or the 'Book of Comfort.' After 39 chapters of judgment and warning, the tone shifts dramatically: 'Comfort, comfort my people, says your God' (Isaiah 40:1). The eagle imagery connects to Deuteronomy 32:11, where God carries Israel on eagles' wings out of Egypt. The promise of renewal echoes the original exodus.
modules.fascinatingFact: Eagles do not flap their wings to soar. They spread their wings and ride thermal currents, ascending without expending energy. Isaiah's metaphor is precise: those who wait on God do not rise through their own exertion. They position themselves to be carried by a power beyond their own. The waiting is the positioning.

modules.heading: The Branch That Stays Connected

modules.ancientTruth: Isaiah promised exiles that those who wait on God will receive exchanged strength: their exhaustion traded for divine power. The waiting is not passive. It is the active binding of hope to promise.
modules.modernApplication: After a week of learning to slow down, find purpose, respond with patience, and extend grace, today's question is: can you sustain it? Not through willpower, but through abiding. The branch bears fruit by staying connected, not by trying harder.
modules.connectionPoint: Chad's ongoing faithfulness, mentoring young leaders and maintaining rhythms of rest and presence years after his initial awakening, embodies Isaiah's promise. His roots produce fruit not because of his effort but because of his connection to the vine.
modules.newTestamentEcho: Jesus said, 'Abide in me, and I in you. As the branch cannot bear fruit by itself, unless it abides in the vine, neither can you, unless you abide in me' (John 15:4). The entire Christian life is sustained connection, not sustained performance.

modules.prompt: How might your rooted presence be a source of peace and purpose for the people around you?
additionalQuestions: How have the small pauses and deliberate rhythms of this week shaped your energy and awareness?
What kind of soil is your life cultivating right now? What needs nurturing?
What one practice from this week do you want to carry forward permanently?

modules.prayerText: Jesus, thank You for rooting me in You amid noise and opposition. Thank You that the strength You offer is not manufactured but exchanged. I give You my exhaustion and receive Your power. Let my presence reflect Your peace and Your purpose. Sustain me not just for service but for lasting, quiet impact. May my life point others to Your faithfulness. Amen.

modules.commitment: I will identify one lasting practice from this week that I will carry forward: a daily pause, a Sabbath rhythm, a soft answer, a surrendered reputation, or a posture of abiding. I will share what I have learned with one person who needs to hear it.
leavingAtCross: The illusion that sustained effort comes from willpower alone
The fear that slowing down means losing relevance
The exhaustion that comes from trying to bear fruit through my own striving
receivingFromCross: Exchanged strength: my weakness traded for God's inexhaustible power
The fruit that comes from abiding rather than achieving
A rooted presence that blesses the people around me without burning me out

Why does Isaiah's sequence move from flying to running to walking, rather than the reverse?
How does Chad's ongoing story of mentoring and sustained faithfulness illustrate Isaiah 40:31?

relatedScriptures.text: And let us not grow weary of doing good, for in due season we will reap, if we do not give up.
Abide in me, and I in you. As the branch cannot bear fruit by itself, unless it abides in the vine, neither can you, unless you abide in me.
Like an eagle that stirs up its nest, that flutters over its young, spreading out its wings, catching them, bearing them on its pinions.
